# Project: TMDb Movie Data - ## Table of Contents
  • Introduction
  • Data Wrangling
  • Exploratory Data Analysis
  • Conclusions
Sarah Alharbi - Data Analysts Nanodegree

## Introduction I am using a TMDb Movie Data set This data set contains information about 10,000 movies collected from The Movie Database (TMDb), including user ratings and revenue. There are 21 columns such as(original title, cast, tagline, etc..) ### Question that can analyised from this data set
  • Average duration of the movie
  • Average runtime of movies from year to year
  • Correlation between revenue and budget
  • Which year has the highest release of movies?

#import statments of all packages that may use.



import numpy as np
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns

%matplotlib inline
## Data Wrangling ### General Properties

# Load your data and print out a few lines. Perform operations to inspect data
# types and look for instances of missing or possibly errant data.

df = pd.read_csv('tmdb-movies.csv')
df.head()
# To know more about the data set (rows, columns)
df.shape
# Summary statistics to know more about data set.
df.describe()

source:
# To cheack the type for each column

df.info()

### Data Cleaning (Removing unused data) > #### Information That We Need To Delete Or Modify
  1. Columns that we may delete are [id, imdb_id, homepage, keywords, tagline, overview, release_date, budget_adj, production_companies, revenue_adj, vote_count, vote_average]
  2. There are some movies in the database have zero budget or zero revenue, Which is there value has not been recorded so we will ignore it.
  3. Reset indexes after removing missing values rows
  4. Removing the duplicacy in the rows(if any).
### 1. Removing Unused columns

# make list contains all unused columns
cols = ['id', 'imdb_id','homepage', 'keywords','tagline', 'overview','release_date','budget_adj', 'production_companies','revenue_adj','vote_count', 'vote_average']

# Using drop to remove unsed columns 
df.drop(cols , axis=1, inplace=True )

source:
# Just to cheack how many zeros values in each columns

df.isin([0]).sum(axis = 0)
#### 2. Removing 0's from budget and the revenue columns

#Drop all missing values in revenue and budget columns
 

df =df[df['budget']!=0].dropna()
df =df[df['revenue']!=0].dropna()
#### 3. Reset indexes after removing rows containing 0 in some columns
df.reset_index(inplace=True)
# To know how the numbers of rows
df.shape
#### 4. Removing the duplicacy in the rows(if any).

# just to cheack there's no duplicates rows
df.duplicated().sum()
## Exploratory Data Analysis ### Research Question 1 (What's the average run time for all movies)
# Using mean to caculate the average
df['runtime'].mean()

plt.figure(figsize=(10,6))

#Title of the graph
plt.title('Runtime of all the movies')



#x-axis label
plt.xlabel('Runtime of the Movies')

#y-axis label
plt.ylabel('Numbers of Movies ')


plt.hist(df['runtime'],rwidth = 0.5,  bins =10)

plt.show()
> The average is 109.2 minutes. Neat, I will use bar graph to show it clearly
### ### Research Question 2 ( Average runtime of movies from year to year)

# Calculate the average of runtime grouping by release year

data1 = df.groupby('release_year').mean()['runtime']

data1.head()

# make a line graph to figures out the trend of the runtime year to year
plt.figure(figsize=(10,6))


plt.plot(data1.index, data1)

plt.xticks(np.arange(1960, 2015, 5)) 


#Title of the graph
plt.title('Release Years Vs. Runtime of Movies')

#x-axis label
plt.xlabel('Release Years')

#y-axis label
plt.ylabel('Runtime of Movies');
> It's obvious that the movie duration decreased from year to year.
### Research Question 2  ( Is there any correlation between Budget and Revenue? )

#scatter plot 

df.plot(figsize=(10,6), x='budget', y='revenue', kind='scatter',title='Budget Vs. Revenue')
plt.show()
> The scatter plot might show a Correlation
#### Calculate the correlation

# To show the correlation between budget and revenue

df['revenue'].corr(df['budget'])
> There is a moderate correlation between budget and revenue.
### Research Question 3 ( Which year has the highest release of movies?)
data = df.groupby('release_year').count()['index']
data.tail(10)
I figured out 2011 had the highest number of movies.

plt.figure(figsize=(10,6))


plt.plot(data.index, data)

plt.xticks(np.arange(1960, 2015, 4)) 


#Title of the graph
plt.title('Release Years Vs. Number of Movies')

#x-axis label
plt.xlabel('Release Years')

#y-axis label
plt.ylabel('Number of Movies');
The line graph showed that 2011 had the highest number of movies(200), followed by 2013 & 2011 had 180,179 movies, respectively.

## Conclusions This was an interesting dataset.
  • The average movie duration is 109 minutes.
  • There is a significant decrease at the movie duration from year to year.
  • There is a moderate correlation between revenue and budget. That's mean if the movie has high budget could has a high revenue as well.
  • The highest number of movies was in 2011 with 200 movies.
### Limitation
  • Removing missing or Null values from revenue and budget columns might skew our analysis and could show unintended bias towards in our analysis.
  • There is no any information about which the currency is used in this dataset nd our analysis is limited to the numerical values of revenue and budget
from subprocess import call
call(['python', '-m', 'nbconvert', 'Investigate_a_Dataset.ipynb'])
